College of Mechanical and Energy Engineering Shaoyang University Shaoyang Hunan 422000 China Catalytic combustion is a flame-free process which occurs at low temperatures and reduces less release of nitric oxide (NOx). Although catalysts help reduce the release of toxic gases, they have detrimental environmental effects. Therefore, by simulation these reactions, a constraint on the flammability limits and improving their performance can be achieved. In this research, using the molecular dynamics (MD) simulation, the catalytic combustion process of air-methane was studied in a helical microchannel. Palladium (Pd) was used as the catalyst. The results show that adding a Pd catalyst further improved the simulated structure's thermal performance(TP). The heat flux(HF) and thermal conductivity (TC) of atomic samples increased from 2067 W/m2 and 1.28 W/m.K to 2096 W/m2 and 1.45 W/m.K with an increase in atomic ratio Pd catalyst from 1 to 4%. Finally, the combustion efficiency (CE) converges to 93% in the presence of 4% Pd catalysts. By increasing the initial pressure (IP) from 0 to 10 bar, the maximum density did not change much, and the velocity and temperature values decrease in terms of the limitation in atomic oscillations. Increasing the IP reduces the HF and TC from 2096 W/m2 and 1.45 W/m.K to 1981 W/m2 and 1.19 W/m.K. Regarding different types of combustion processes, such as catalytic combustion, were considered in different types of industrial applications, it is expected to study the effect of the parameters of the atomic ratio of Pd catalyst and the IP, propose an optimal mechanism to create catalytic combustion in real and practical samples. A catalyst is a substance which can be obtained at the end of a reaction without undergoing a chemical change [18]. Combustion process of methane and the effects of methane and oxygen on heat/mass transfer were examined by many researchers [19,20]. This substance affects the reaction rate and increases it. Catalytic combustion is a flame-free process which occurs at low temperatures. Therefore, it releases less NOx [21,22]. This combustion usually consists of a preheater and a catalyst, and even though cold catalytic systems are currently operating at ambient temperature, they do not require a preheater [23–26]. Palladium was used as the catalyst or other photocatalytic Applications [27]. There is no direct flame in such a system, although the catalyst's surface has luminosity. The efficiency of such combustions depends on many factors, including the concentration of pollutant, gas flow temperature, oxygen concentration at the time of contact, and the type of catalyst [23,28]. Achieving a return of more than 90% seems impossible in this process. Catalytic combustion processes are used to control the emission of hydrocarbons and carbon monoxide. Although catalysts help reduce the release of toxic gases, they have environmental effects. Therefore, by simulating these reactions, a constraint on the flammability limits and improving their performance can be achieved. So far, various studies were performed on the catalytic combustion of different structures. For example, in an experimental study, Lee and Trim [29] studied the catalytic combustion process of methane. This study shows that using Pd catalysts caused the process of catalytic combustion. Hence, after this process, methane was converted into water molecules and CO2. Ciuparu et al. [30] reviewed previous studies on catalytic combustion of methane structure to study the effective parameters in this process. They showed that temperature and pressure were among the most important parameters to effect catalytic combustion processes. In computational research, Yan et al. [31] studied the effect of simulated sample dimensions on the catalytic combustion process. The results of this study, which was performed using the finite element method, show an increase in the thermal efficiency of simulated samples by reducing the dimensions of the sample on a micrometre scale. Feng et al. [32] studied the effect of adding strontium nanoparticles to the Co/CeO2 primary catalyst and showed that the TP of fluid improved during the combustion process by adding these nanoparticles and atomic pollution. Feng et al. [33] investigated the catalytic combustion process in the presence of a toluene catalyst. This study adds CeO2 nanoparticles with different percentages to the primary toluene catalyst. The results show that the catalytic combustion process could be observed at lower temperatures using the optimal ratio of these nanoparticles and nanopollutations. Although catalysts help reduce the emission of toxic gases, they have harmful environmental effects. During the conversion of hydrocarbons and CO, CO2 is produced. This gas is one of the main greenhouse gases, the main factor in global warming. By helping CO2, these gas “catalysts” sometimes convert nitrogen and oxygen compounds into nitrous oxide. This gas, also known as “nitro”, is the same gas used to increase the speed of the car, and it is 377 times stronger than CO2 in warming the earth. Therefore, by simulating these reactions, it is possible to achieve limits for flammability and improve their performance [34]. Previous studies show that various factors, such as temperature, pressure, nanoparticle volume fraction, type of catalyst, etc., affect the catalytic combustion process. The effect of IP and the atomic ratio of Pd catalyst on the catalytic combustion process of air-methane was not studied. This study uses the MD simulations in a helical coil microchannel. Because laboratory measurements at micro and nano scales were difficult, the MD simulation could provide relatively detailed images of surface-level phenomena. They could be used to understand the TP of these structures. Regarding different types of combustion processes, such as catalytic combustion, were considered in different types of industrial applications, it is expected to study the effect of the parameters of the atomic ratio of the Pd catalyst and the IP, propose an optimal mechanism to create catalytic combustion in real and practical samples. 2 Simulation 2.1 MD simulation MD simulation is one of the most powerful tools to obtain macroscopic and microscopic properties of materials. Especially for quantities whose experimental values are difficult to obtain under unusual conditions, the MD technique can be used. In the MD method, system changes are obtained by integrating the equations of motion. First, the initial position of particles is determined based on an initial configuration model to determine and distribute the equilibrium velocity of particles from the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution equation [35]. The basis of MD simulation was selecting the appropriate interaction potential among the particles. The closer this potential was to the actual potential among the particles, the better the model of reality. In computer simulations, intermolecular and intramolecular forces were expressed as a set of mathematical equations and were very important in the accuracy of the simulation results. Consequently, the main problem was finding the interaction between atoms and the forces acting on them at any given moment. The choice of an interatomic potential, the mode of interaction of atoms, was certainly the main input for developing an atomic model; Therefore, the potential energy of the whole molecular system was the sum of intermolecular intramolecular energies. In the present simulation, Lennard-Jones (LJ), Embedded Atom Model (EAM), and Coulomb potential functions were used to examine the interaction potential of particles [29–31]. The potential function of EAM represents the common model of atomic bonding in metal systems and is represented as follows [39]: (6) U i = ∑ i = 1 N − 1 ∑ j = i + 1 N ϕ ( r i j ) + ∑ i = 1 N F ( ρ i ) (7) ρ i = ∑ i = 1 N ψ ( r i j ) here, ψ ( r i j ) and F(ρi) represent the interatomic energy and potential embedding function. The bond energy and bond distance among the atoms at the common surface with each other, according to the Lorentz-Bertolt mixing law, are obtained as follows [41]: (9) ε i j = ε i ε j (10) σ i j = σ i + σ j 2 Finally, Coulomb potential function was used to determine the forces of static electric charges of the attraction or repeller particles and is represented as follows [43]: (11) U i j ( r ) = − 1 4 π ε 0 q i q j r i j 2 here, ε0 is the vacuum electric permittivity (8.85 × 10−12 F/m). 2.2 Present simulation details Using the MD method, air-methane's catalytic combustion process was studied in a helical microchannel made of iron and copper. This study uses the LAMMPS software (an open-source code) to perform all calculations. The air-methane was considered the fuel, and Pd was used as the catalyst. Since the stoichiometric amount of oxygen inside the simulation box creates the most optimal state in the samples and, as a result, it will be the best option in the field of heat transfer, in this study, the stoichiometric ratio of diatomic oxygen molecules to methane molecule is observed with a ratio of 2:1. Initial structures were modelled with Avogadro software. In this study, 1500 methane molecules and 3000 diatomic oxygen molecules have been modelled for initial structures. The dimension of the simulation box was considered 1 × 1 × 1 μm3 with a fixed boundary condition in all directions. The IP and temperature were set to 0 bar and 300 K. The simulation time was regarded. The simulation time was considered 20 ns with a 1 fs time step. NPT ensemble was used to control IP and temperature. By choosing constant boundary conditions, the size of atomic structures is fixed in three directions, and the atomic system is repeated in selected directions by choosing periodic boundary conditions. To implement the combustion process in this sample, the initial and final pressure and temperature settings should be determined so that the combustion process can be implemented by raising the temperature in the simulation box. As a result, the temperature and pressure of the simulated structures will be equilibrated using the Nose-Hoover thermostat and the large focal tube (NPT). In the first step of the simulation, the structure will be equilibrated at room temperature (377 K). And after ensuring the atomic stability and thermodynamic equilibration of the simulated sample, the temperature of the sample will be increased until the combustion process occurs. A view of the atomic structure during the combustion process is represented in Fig. 1 . Afte examined the stability of structures, the ensemble changed to NVE, and the combustion process. 2.3 Stability process The equilibrium process in atomic samples at a temperature of 300 K and 0 bar was studied by examining kinetic and potential energy changes. Fig. 2 shows the simulated sample's kinetic energy changes over simulation time. The kinetic energy in the present simulation converged to a numerical value of 96 eV after 10 ns. Convergence of kinetic energy of atomic samples to a certain value resulting from a decrease in the oscillation amplitude of this quantity will indicate equilibrium in atomic samples. This behavior indicated the proper definition of atomic structures and interatomic potentials. This factor caused the distance among the atoms in the structures to tend to a certain value, and as a result, the amount of kinetic energy of the atomic samples did not diverge. Studying potential energy changes in atomic samples was another important factor in the MD simulation. The numerical value of the potential energy in an atomic sample indicated its atomic stability. Fig. 3 shows the changes in potential energy in the simulated atomic sample over simulation time. According to Fig. 3, the atomic structure simulated using the MD simulation method had good stability. The potential energy in atomic samples indicated the presence of an attractive force among the atomic samples and, consequently, the atomic stability. From a numerical point of view, the amount of potential energy in the modelled structure converged to -278 eV after 10 ns. The negative value reported in this section showed the presence of an atomic attraction force inside the simulation box. The interatomic attraction force in the simulated samples caused the interatomic distance in the atomic structure not to increase. The atoms were placed next to each other and at a small distance. It preserved the continuity of the atomic sample. The negative amount of potential energy in the sample indicated the presence of an attractive force among the atoms after 10 ns. 3 Results 3.1 The atomic ratio of the catalyst A catalyst is a substance that, if added to a reaction mixture, changes the rate at which the substance reaches equilibrium in the system without undergoing a stable chemical change and usually increases it. Catalysts may be homogeneous or heterogeneous. Theoretically, the catalyst can be obtained at the end of the reaction without undergoing chemical change, although it may be physically altered. Although the catalyst can affect the reaction rate, it can not change the equilibrium position in a reversible reaction. The addition of a catalyst could improve the TP of the simulated prototype. Therefore, in the first computational step, a Pd catalyst with atomic ratios of 1, 2, 4, 6, and 10% was added to the initial fluid, and the atomic and TP were evaluated. Fig. 4 shows the atomic samples with the catalyst in the initial and final steps. Fig. 5 shows the change in maximum density in the presence of Pd catalysts with different ratios. The results show that adding a Pd catalyst with an atomic ratio of 1% and up to an atomic ratio of 4% had an upward trend. Finally, the value of this quantity converged to 0.115 atom/Å3. Numerical values related to the maximum density value in the presence of Pd catalysts are presented in Table 2 . Fig. 6 shows the changes in the maximum velocity of simulated atomic samples in the presence of Pd catalysts with different ratios. The results show that adding 1% Pd catalyst increased the maximum velocity to 0.45 Å/ps. By increasing the atomic ratio of a Pd catalyst, the velocity value had an upward trend. The atomic ratio of 4% reached the maximum velocity value, which is 0.52 Å/ps. After reaching the maximum value, the numerical value of the velocity decreased, and finally, in the atomic ratio of 10%, this quantity decreased to 0.46. Using the presented results, by increasing the atomic ratio of the catalyst in atomic samples, the velocity in atomic samples decreased, which resulted from reducing atomic oscillations in terms of the space constraint created. Fig. 7 shows the changes in maximum temperature in simulated atomic samples in the presence of Pd catalysts at different ratios. As the velocity of particles increases, so does the temperature in the atomic structure. The temperature in the samples increased to a numerical value of 584 K with a 4% atomic ratio of Pd. As the atomic ratio of the catalyst increased further, as the particle velocity decreased, so did the temperature. With the presence of a 10% of catalyst, its value increased to 503 K. Numerical values related to the maximum temperature value in Pd catalysts are presented in Table 2. After ensuring the structural equilibration in the simulated samples, the amount of HF, TC, and CE will express the TP of the samples. Fig. 8 shows the changes in HF in a simulated atomic sample with the addition of different atomic ratios of Pd catalysts. According to the presented results, it can be seen that by adding 1% Pd catalyst, the HF reached 2067 W/m2. By increasing the atomic ratio of the catalyst to 4%, the amount of HF reached the maximum value. Then by increasing the atomic ratio of the catalyst, the HF had a decreasing trend. From a numerical point of view, increasing the atomic ratio of the catalyst from 4% to 10% decreased the HF from 2096 to 2055 W/m2. Fig. 9 shows the TC changes in the simulated atomic sample using a different atomic ratio of Pd catalysts. The results show that by increasing the atomic ratio of the catalyst, the TC increased, and after reaching the maximum value, it went through a downward trend. Increasing the atomic ratio of the Pd catalyst from 1 to 4%, the TC reaches from 1.28 to 1.45 W/m.K. Besides, by increasing the atomic ratio of the catalyst from 4 to 10%, the TC decreased and finally reached 1.30 W/m.K. The results are presented in more detail in Table 3 . Fig. 10 shows the CE changes in the simulated atomic sample with the addition of different atomic ratios of Pd catalysts. The results show that the addition of a Pd catalyst further improved the TP of the initial fluid. This behavior was in terms of the increasing atomic mobility in the modelled samples in return for the addition of Pd catalyst, corresponding to the increase in oscillation amplitude in the defined samples. On the other hand, this improvement reached its maximum value by adding 4% of the catalyst to the initial structure. Consequently, the simulated sample showed higher thermal efficiency for different catalysts. By further increasing the atomic ratio of the catalyst in the simulated samples, the aggregation process reduced the thermal efficiency in the optimized sample. From a numerical point of view, the amount of HF and conductivity of atomic samples with the addition of 4% Pd catalyst reached 2096 W/m2 and 1.45 W/m.K, which was the maximum value obtained based on Table 2. Numerical values related to the change in HF, TC, and CE values in Pd catalysts are presented in Table 2. 3.2 The effect of IP The IP was an effective factor in the simulation fluid combustion process. Therefore, in this section, the effect of the IP on the atomic and TP of fluid was studied. The IP inside the simulation box was in 0, 1, 2, 5 and 10 bar values. Fig. 11 shows the atomic evolution of the fluid understudy at the IP combustion process 1, 2, 5, and 10 bar. Fig. 12 shows the changes in the maximum density of simulated atomic samples at different IPs. The results defined did not change much for different IP values. In other words, by increasing the IP of the atomic sample from 0 to 10 bar, the maximum density value decreased from 0.118 to 0.117 atom/Å3. Fig. 13 shows the maximum velocities in atomic samples simulated at different IPs. According to the results in Table 6, the atomic samples’ velocity decreased by increasing pressure and converged to a value of 0.35 Å/ps at 10 bar. This decrease in the value of velocity profiles was the limitation of atomic oscillations inside the simulation box, which could directly affect the TP of the sample under study. On the other hand, increasing the IP does not disrupt the atomic structure. As a result, the system designed in this study could be used in different environmental conditions. Fig. 14 shows the change in the maximum temperature of simulated atomic samples at different IPs. According to the results presented in Table 6, the maximum temperature in atomic samples decreased by increasing IP and converged to a numerical value of 441 K at a pressure of 10 bar. This decrease in the value of the temperature profile was the limitation of the atomic oscillations inside the simulation box with increasing IP, which could directly affect the TP of the sample under study Table 4 . Considering the kinetic constraints created in atomic samples and the effect of atomic velocities on the amount of IP in the simulated samples, it is expected that the TP of these samples will also change. The heat fluctuations in the simulated atomic sample for different IPs are shown in Fig. 15 . According to the results presented in Table 7, increasing the IP from 0 to 10 bar in atomic samples reduces the HF flowing in atomic samples from 2096 to 1981 W/m2. Fig. 16 shows the changes in the TC of simulated atomic samples at different IPs. The results show that increasing the IP up to 10 bar decreased the TC from 1.45 to 1.19 W/m.K. the numerical results are listed in Table 5 . As the HF and TC decreased, the CE of the atomic samples was expected to decrease. Fig. 17 shows the CE changes in the simulated atomic sample for different IPs. According to the presented results, by increasing the IP from 0 to 10 bar, the numerical value of CE decreased from 93 to 79%. This can be evaluated by reducing the participation of atoms present in the simulation box in the combustion process and should be considered in practical applications of the thermal structure introduced in the present study because the defined initial conditions could disrupt the behavior of the proposed heating system. 4 Conclusion In summary, the present study investigated the catalytic combustion process of air-methane in a helical coil microchannel. This study was performed by simulating MD in 10 ns. In the first step of the research, the equilibrium process in atomic samples at a temperature of 300 K and 0 bar was studied by examining kinetic and potential energy changes. Finally, the atomic behavior of the structure was studied with changes in maximum density, temperature, and velocity, and TP were studied by examining changes in HF, TC and CE. The following general results were obtained: • As the atomic ratio of the Pd catalyst in the atomic samples increased (to 4%), the velocity and temperature in the atomic samples increased. • Adding a Pd catalyst to 4% improves the TP of the samples. In the presence of a 4% Pd catalyst, the structures’ TC, HF, and CE reached 1.45 W/m.K, 2096 W/m2, and 93%, respectively. This increase was in terms of increased atomic mobility in the modelled samples with the addition of the catalyst, which will correspond to the increase in oscillation amplitude in the defined samples. • The results for the maximum density of the sample defined did not change much for different IP values. Increasing the IP from 0 to 10 bar, the maximum velocity and temperature in atomic samples decrease and converge to 0.35 Å/ps and 441 K. • Increased pressure in atomic samples reduces the TP of structures. More precisely, by increasing the IP to 10 bar, the HF flowing in the atomic samples decreased from 2096 to 1981 W/m2. The TC and CE decreased to 1.19 W/m.K and 79%. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic combustion is a flame-free process which occurs at low temperatures and reduces less release of nitric oxide (NOx). Although catalysts help reduce the release of toxic gases, they have detrimental environmental effects. Therefore, by simulation these reactions, a constraint on the flammability limits and improving their performance can be achieved. In this research, using the molecular dynamics (MD) simulation, the catalytic combustion process of air-methane was studied in a helical microchannel. Palladium (Pd) was used as the catalyst. The results show that adding a Pd catalyst further improved the simulated structure's thermal performance(TP). The heat flux(HF) and thermal conductivity (TC) of atomic samples increased from 2067 W/m2 and 1.28 W/m.K to 2096 W/m2 and 1.45 W/m.K with an increase in atomic ratio Pd catalyst from 1 to 4%. Finally, the combustion efficiency (CE) converges to 93% in the presence of 4% Pd catalysts. By increasing the initial pressure (IP) from 0 to 10 bar, the maximum density did not change much, and the velocity and temperature values decrease in terms of the limitation in atomic oscillations. Increasing the IP reduces the HF and TC from 2096 W/m2 and 1.45 W/m.K to 1981 W/m2 and 1.19 W/m.K. Regarding different types of combustion processes, such as catalytic combustion, were considered in different types of industrial applications, it is expected to study the effect of the parameters of the atomic ratio of Pd catalyst and the IP, propose an optimal mechanism to create catalytic combustion in real and practical samples.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of a palladium catalyst and initial pressure on methane-air catalytic combustion process in a helical coil microchannel: A molecular dynamics approach
